sen.j: 花脊峠（はなせとうげ）は京都府京都市左京区内にある国道上の峠である。
sen.e: Hanase-toge Pass is a pass on a highway in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Hanase-toge Pass is a pass on a national route in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

tit.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 標高769mの国道477号上に位置する峠である。
sen.e: It is 769m above sea level and it is on National Highway 477.
It is the pass located on National Route 477 at an altitude of 769 meters.
It is the pass located on National Route 477 at an altitude of 769 meters.

sen.j: 三重県と大阪府を繋ぎ、紀伊半島を内陸に迂回する国道477号の長大なルート上で最も高い標高に位置する峠である。
sen.e: It is the highest pass on the very long highway, National Highway 477, which connects Mie Prefecture and Osaka Prefecture along the Kii-hanto Peninsula.
It is the highest pass on the very long National Route 477, which connects Mie Prefecture and Osaka Prefecture with taking the route inland of Kii-hanto Peninsula.
It is the highest pass on the very long National Route 477, which connects Mie Prefecture and Osaka Prefecture with taking the route inland of Kii-hanto Peninsula.

sen.j: 名前の由来は花の美しい北山の懐にあるので「花の背」とよばれたから、花の都京都の北の背骨に位置するところにあるからなど諸説ある。
sen.e: There are various views on the origin of its name 'Hanase (flower back)': one view is that the pass run through Mt. Kita which have been famous for beautiful flowers, so once people had called it 'Hana-no-se (the back covered with flowers)', another view is that for a long time the pass had carried out the function of the northern backbone (a major transportation route) of Kyoto which had been called 'Hana-no-miyako (the capital city flourishing like flowers)'.
sen.cmt: *Japanese also call some parts of mountains '背(せ)back'.
sen.e: There are various views on the origin of its name 'Hanase' (flower back): some is that the pass was called 'Hana no se' (the back covered with flowers) as it runs through the heart of Mt. Kita which have been famous for beautiful flowers, others is that the pass is located at so-called north backbone of Kyoto which was 'Hana-no-miyako' (the capital city flourishing), and so on.

sen.j: また脊という字は一般的に「背」を用いるが、本来は「脊」の字が正しい。
sen.e: Hanase-toge is usually written as '花背峠', however originally it had been written as '花脊峠' ('背' and '脊' is different character and have the nearly same meaning).

sen.j: ちなみにこの峠より北側は花脊別所町、南側は鞍馬本町となっている。
sen.e: On the north side of the pass is Hanase-bessho-cho, on the south side of the pass is Kurama-honmachi.
Incidentally, On the north side of the pass is Hanase-bessho-cho, on the south side is Kurama-honmachi.

sen.j: 車両の通行が可能な峠であり、センターラインこそないが2.0車線はゆうにある広い道路を有する峠である。
sen.e: The road is more than two lanes wide, and although there aren't centerlines, normal cars can run through it easily and safely.
Vehicles can run through the pass which has the wide road with more than two lanes wide, with no centerline.
Vehicles can run through the pass which has the wide road with more than two lanes wide, with no centerline.

sen.j: この峠は冬季通行止めにはならないが、除雪の関係で積雪時には道幅が狭まる。
sen.e: The pass is not closed for the winter, however the road become narrower when the snow is heaped up.
The pass is not closed in the winter, however the road become narrower when the snow is heaped up.

sen.j: また京都バスの路線が通過しており、峠には「花脊峠」というバス停があって、登山客が主に利用している。
sen.e: Kyoto Bus runs through it and there is a bus stop 'Hanase-toge' on the pass, which is used mainly by climbers.
Kyoto Bus runs through the pass where bus stop called 'Hanase-toge' is located and is used by mainly climbers.

sen.j: また勾配は急であり、隣接する百井峠程ではないが、麓の百井別れや九十九折れなども含めて酷道と呼ばれる区間である。
sen.e: It is a little easier to drive than the neighboring pass 'Momoi-toge Pass', however it is still notorious for the steep slopes and narrow winding sections ('Momoi-wakare' and 'Tuzura-ore') at the foot of the pass.
It is the steep slope zone called 'kokudo' (a deplorable road) including Momoi-wakare curve at the foot and Tsukumo-ore curve and so on.
